question.text: Parathyroid hormone secretion increases in response to

options.text: a decrease in blood calcium levels
increased secretion of parathyroid-releasing hormone from the hypothalamus.
increased production of parathyroid-stimulating hormone from the anterior pituitary

solution.text: Thyroid is the largest endocrine in our body. It is butterfly shaped and situated in the neck region. It consists of two lobes on either side of trachea that are connected by isthmus. Each lobe consists of many follicles that secrete thyroid hormones that control metabolism of the body. In between follicles are parafollicular cells that secrete calcitonin. On the posterior side of thyroid, two pairs of parathyroid glands are seen and these secrete PTH (Parathormone). Calcitonin and Parathormone maintain calcium metabolism. Calcitonin causes blood calcium level to decrease. This is done by deposition of calcium in bones, increasing absorption of calcium by kidneys etc. Parathormone is antagonist to calcitonin. Its main function is to increase calcium in plasma and thus decrease in plasma levels triggers its release.
